coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous electrocatalysis usually involves the charge transfer between the surface of electrocatalysts and corresponding reactants. Thus, modulating the surface electron density of electrocatalysts is an effective strategy to boost the electrocatalytic activity of targeted reactions. Herein, the NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction is constructed via a simple selenization method for both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR). The designed NiSe2/FeSe2 electrocatalyst exhibits a superior activity towards OER, which only requires a low overpotential of 256 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2, and surpasses other selenides and even the state-of-the-art RuO2. Impressively, when employed as the UOR electrode, the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction needs only 127 mV overpotential at 50 mA cm-2, remarkably superior to other selenides and confirming the less energy consumption for UOR. The comprehensive analysis demonstrates that the well-designed built-in electric field at the heterointerface of NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction due to the difference of energy levels can expedite the charge transfer and thus strengthen the conductivity of heterojunction electrocatalyst. Moreover, the self-driven electron transfer across the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterointerface can induce local charge redistribution at the interface region, which is beneficial for the adsorption of OH− and urea owing to the electrostatic interaction. Therefore, the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction with regulated electronic structure displays extraordinary electrocatalytic activity for both the OER and UOR. This study demonstrates a novel strategy to manipulate the surface/interface charge states of electrocatalysts for improving the catalytic activity of OER and UOR, and provides new guidelines for exploring other superior electrocatalysts.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction with built-in electric-field effects is constructed by a facile selenization strategy and shows superior electrocatalytic activity towards oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR).

Heterogeneous electrocatalysis usually involves the charge transfer between the surface of electrocatalysts and corresponding reactants. Thus, modulating the surface electron density of electrocatalysts is an effective strategy to boost the electrocatalytic activity of targeted reactions. Herein, the NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction is constructed via a simple selenization method for both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR). The designed NiSe2/FeSe2 electrocatalyst exhibits a superior activity towards OER, which only requires a low overpotential of 256 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2, and surpasses other selenides and even the state-of-the-art RuO2. Impressively, when employed as the UOR electrode, the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction needs only 127 mV overpotential at 50 mA cm-2, remarkably superior to other selenides and confirming the less energy consumption for UOR. The comprehensive analysis demonstrates that the well-designed built-in electric field at the heterointerface of NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction due to the difference of energy levels can expedite the charge transfer and thus strengthen the conductivity of heterojunction electrocatalyst. Moreover, the self-driven electron transfer across the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterointerface can induce local charge redistribution at the interface region, which is beneficial for the adsorption of OH− and urea owing to the electrostatic interaction. Therefore, the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction with regulated electronic structure displays extraordinary electrocatalytic activity for both the OER and UOR. This study demonstrates a novel strategy to manipulate the surface/interface charge states of electrocatalysts for improving the catalytic activity of OER and UOR, and provides new guidelines for exploring other superior electrocatalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: Electrochemical water splitting driven by the renewable electricity has been deemed as an appealing method for sustainable energy development without reliance on fossil fuels [1,2]. However, a drawback is that the efficiency of hydrogen production is severely limited by the thermodynamically sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode [3], which leads to the high energy depletion and expensive cost of production for water electrolysis. Therefore, developing high-efficiency electrocatalysts and alternative anodic oxidation reactions are urgently required to lower the driving voltage and promote its practical employment [4,5].

Urea oxidation reaction (UOR) has attracted much attention recently as it allows to produce hydrogen and alleviate urea-rich wastewater concurrently [6]. UOR requires a much lower thermodynamic voltage (0.37 V) than OER (1.23 V), and thus is beneficial for the energy saving and boosting the energy efficiency of hydrogen production [7]. Nevertheless, the UOR is still restricted by the intrinsically sluggish kinetics, which is caused by the complicated six-electron transfer process and the various adsorption and desorption of corresponding intermediates [8,9]. Thus, exploring high-performance electrocatalysts for both the OER and UOR is greatly desirable for achieving the large-scale implementation of energy-saving hydrogen production. Despite noble-metal based electrocatalysts, such as RuO2 and IrO2, have exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity for OER and UOR, their real applications are impeded by the high price and scarcity [10]. Lately, a series of transition-metal based materials, for example, sulfides [11–13], oxides [14–16], and selenides [17–19] have been explored with commendable catalytic performance for OER and UOR. Especially, transition metal selenides possess better conductivity due to the smaller ionization energy and larger atomic radius in comparison with the corresponding sulfides and oxides [20], which conduces to faster electron transfer and thus improved its electrocatalytic activity. Whereas, the OER and UOR activity of transition metal selenides requires to be further improved for satisfying the actual demands.

As is known to all, heterogeneous electrocatalysis typically contains electron transfer as well as adsorption and desorption of reactants and products occurring on the surface of electrocatalysts [21]. Hence, the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts is greatly dependent on the surface charge state of constructed materials [22,23]. Up to now, multitudinous efforts have been devoted to manipulating the surface electron state of synthesized electrocatalysts for boosting the catalytic activity, such as heteroatom doping [24,25], interface engineering [26,27], and phase controlling [28,29]. As indicated by the semiconductor physics, constructing heterojunction systems with two semiconductors of different energy structures can result in the formation of a built-in electric field and two opposite charge distribution regions at the heterojunction interface [30]. The built-in field can boost the electron transport during electrocatalytic process, and the special space-charge region would have the potential to influence the adsorption of corresponding reactants [31]. Accordingly, the design and fabrication of p-p selenides heterojunction would be a valuable strategy for enhancing the catalytic performance of materials towards OER and UOR, but it has seldom been investigated for both the OER and UOR so far. Furthermore, Prussian blue (PB) and PB analogs (PBAs), which are formed by the coordination interaction between the cyanide and metal centers, have been regarded as promising precursors for fabricating various transition metal compounds due to the facile preparation method and adjustable compositions [32]. Then, from the PBAs platform, constructing p-p selenides semiconductor hybrids with a built-in electric field is deemed to be intriguing towards exploring a high-efficiency electrocatalyst for OER and UOR.

Inspired by the above motivations, herein, the p-p NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction was synthesized via a feasible solid-state selenization strategy with Fe-Ni PBA as the precursor. Remarkably, the constructed NiSe2/FeSe2 electrocatalyst exhibits the excellent electrocatalytic performance for both OER and UOR in alkaline KOH solution. More importantly, the various physicochemical characterizations as well as electrochemical measurements confirm that the enhanced catalytic activity of the NiSe2/FeSe2 should be attributed to the built-in electric field at the heterointerface induced by the difference of respective energy level. The built-in electric field is in favor of boosting the electron transfer and forming the space-charge region at the heterointerface, thereby contributing to the improved conductivity and enhanced adsorption of targeted reactants. Therefore, constructing a built-in electric field for engineering the surface electronic structure would be a promising strategy for enhancing the catalytic performance of electrocatalysts in the future.

Prussian blue (Fe4[Fe(CN)6]3), potassium hexacyanocobaltate(III) (K3Co(CN)6), ruthenium dioxide (RuO2), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), selenium powder (Se) and sodium citrate (C6H5O7Na3) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). Ferrous chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2·4H2O) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were purchased from Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. Nafion solution (5 wt%) and potassium tetracyanonikelate(II) hydrate (K2Ni(CN)4·xH2O) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All these reagents were of analytical grade and can be utilized directly. The water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ cm was obtained via a Millipore system.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of corresponding Prussian-blue analog precursors (PBAs)
ce:section.ce:para: Synthesis of Co-Co PBA: 1.43 g of CoCl2·6H2O and 2.32 g of C6H5O7Na3 were dissolved in 200 mL of water for forming solution A. 1.33 g of K3Co(CN)6 was dissolved in 200 mL of water for forming solution B. Then, solution B was added to solution A under magnetic stirring. After successive stirring for 10 min, the resulting mixed solution was aged at room temperature for 24 h. Then, the precipitate was obtained through centrifugation, washed with ethanol and water, and dried at 70 °C overnight.

Synthesis of Ni-Ni PBA: 0.95 g of NiCl2·6H2O and 0.77 g of C6H5O7Na3 were dissolved in 200 mL of water for forming solution A. 0.96 g of K2Ni(CN)4·xH2O was dissolved in 200 mL of water for forming solution B. And the subsequent synthesis steps are similar with the Co-Co PBA.
Synthesis of Fe-Ni PBA: the preparation steps were as same as Ni-Ni PBA by using 0.79 g FeCl2·4H2O instead of NiCl2·6H2O.
Synthesis of Co-Ni PBA: the preparation steps were also as same as Ni-Ni PBA by using 0.95 g CoCl2·6H2O instead of NiCl2·6H2O.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of corresponding transition metal selenides
ce:section.ce:para: Synthesis of FeSe2: 0.2 g Prussian blue and 0.40 g Se powder were added into an agate mortar. After being grinded for 0.5 h, the generated homogeneous mixture was poured into the ceramic crucible. Then, the crucible was put in the tube furnace and annealed at 500 °C in Ar atmosphere under a heating rate of 1 °C min−1 for 2 h. When the tube furnace was cooled to room temperature, the final product FeSe2 was synthesized.

For comparison, the CoSe2, NiSe2, NiSe2/FeSe2, and NiSe2/CoSe2 were prepared with the similar method as FeSe2 by using Co-Co PBA, Ni-Ni PBA, Fe-Ni PBA, and Co-Ni PBA instead of Prussian blue, respectively.

The morphology and structure of samples were investigated via the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Zeiss Sigma300), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-F200), as well as powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, X’PERT PRO MPD, Cu Kα radiation). After the synthesized materials were degassed at 120 °C for 12 h with the high vacuum, the N2 adsorption-desorption measurements of samples were conducted on the Autosorb-IQ instrument under 77 K. The Raman microscope (Renishaw inVia) was employed for obtaining the Raman spectra of synthesized samples under the laser wavelengths of 532 nm. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Kratos Axis Ultra DLD) with Al Kα radiation was performed for investigating the chemical state of samples. These acquired XPS spectra were calibrated through the binding energy of C 1s peak (284.8 eV). Ultraviolet photoemission spectroscopy (UPS) was acquired through the Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi under a monochromatic light source of He I (21.2 eV). The ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, UV2450) with barium sulfate as the reference was employed for collecting the UV–vis diffuse-reflectance. The concentrations of transition metals in obtained catalysts were measured using the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer).

All electrochemical characterizations were conducted on the CHI 660E electrochemical workstation by a standard three-electrode configuration in KOH (1.0 M) solution with or without urea (0.33 M). For the working electrode, counter electrode, and reference electrode, the catalyst-modified carbon cloth, platinum plate as well as saturated Ag/AgCl were employed, respectively. To prepare an electrocatalyst-decorated carbon cloth electrode, a certain of electrocatalyst (4 mg) was dispersed into the mixing solution containing ethanol (500 μL), Nafion (30 μL, 5 wt%), as well as water (470 μL) via sonicating of 1 h for forming homogeneous ink. Afterwards, the resulting solution (22.5 μL) was dripped on the carbon cloth (1 × 3 cm2) for obtaining the desired working electrode (0.3 mg cm−2). The measured potential (EAg/AgCl) was converted into reversible hydrogen electrode potential (ERHE) according to the following equation: ERHE = 0.197 V + 0.059 × pH + EAg/AgCl. In advance of the measurement, the acquired solution was purified through high-purity oxygen gas for at least 30 min. Next, by virtue of the CV method, the carbon cloth was swept at 20 cycles from 1 to 1.8 V (vs RHE) for obtaining the steady current. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were conducted at a scan speed of 5 mV s-1 with the correction of ohmic potential drop (iR, 95 %). In the light of following equation: η = ERHE – 1.23, the overpotential (η) was obtained. The Tafel slopes were further calculated from LSV data based on the formula: η = a × log|j| + b (a denotes the Tafel slope, b devotes the intercept, as well as j denotes the current density). The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was investigated through testing corresponding electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl). CV measurements were performed at various scan rates (from 20 to 140 mV/s) in the non-Faradaic region (1.0–1.1 V vs. RHE). The values of Cdl were obtained by calculating the half slope of the differences for the current density of 1.05 V (vs. RHE) at different scan rates. The ECSA was acquired via a formula: ECSA = A × Cdl / Cs, where Cs devotes the specific capacitance for electrode of a smooth planar surface (0.004 mF cm2), as well as A is the geometric area of carbon cloth (0.3 cm2). The formula (jECSA = j / ECSA) was employed for obtaining the current density normalized via the value of ECSA. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was investigated at the potential perturbation of 10 mV amplitude in the frequency range between 100 kHz and 1 Hz. For evaluating the durability of catalyst, the chronoamperometry (i-t) measurement was conducted at the fixed bias for 10 mA cm−2. After the durability measurement, the LSV curve test was also performed. The Mott-Schottky curves were tested in the above-mentioned three-electrode instrument and acquired over an AC frequency of 1 kHz with the potential region of 0.4–1.2 V (vs. Ag/AgCl).

The NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction was fabricated via a two-step process, including the precipitation growth of Fe-Ni PBA precursor then followed by a low-temperature selenization procedure. And the detailed fabrication procedures are provided in the Experiment Section. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed to investigate the morphology of as-prepared samples. As presented in Fig. S1a, b, the Fe-Ni PBA exhibits a plate-like configuration with a smooth surface. After the corresponding selenization procedure, the plate-like Fe-Ni PBA precursor change into the block-shaped structure with a size of hundreds of nanometers (Fig. 1 a, b), which can be attributed to the structural collapse of the PBA induced by the metal-cyanide breaking as well as metal-selenium forming [33]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was further employed for probing the morphology and microstructure of the constructed electrocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 1c, the TEM image shows the NiSe2/FeSe2 particles of hundreds of nanometers in size. In Fig. 1e (magnified region marked by the red box in Fig. 1d), it should be noticed that distinct lattice fringes and the interface between NiSe2 and FeSe2 exist. The interplanar spacing of 0.266 nm can be indexed to the (210) plane of NiSe2 [34], and the interplanar distance of 0.248 nm can be attributed to the (012) plane of FeSe2 [35], which confirms the successful construction of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction. Moreover, the high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) image and the corresponding energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) element mapping images have demonstrated that the Ni, Fe, and Se elements are evenly distributed among the whole regions of as-prepared samples (Fig. 1f), further illustrating the successful preparation of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction but not simply recombination of NiSe2 and FeSe2. The atomic ratio of Ni: Fe is 1.16: 1 according to the result of inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (Table S1), which is well consistent with the EDS result (Fig. S2). Notably, the tight contact between NiSe2 and FeSe2 in NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction can induce strong electronic interaction at the interface and thus enhance the electrocatalytic performance, which can be verified by the following spectroscopic and electrochemical analysis.

The crystal information of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction was analyzed via the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). As displayed in Fig. 2 a, all the diffraction peaks can be well indexed into the standard PDF cards of NiSe2 (JCPDF #88-1711) and FeSe2 (JCPDF #74-0247) [34,35], which is well coincident with the above TEM results, further confirming that NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction was formed successfully. Furthermore, nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurement was also carried out for characterizing the surface area as well as pore structure of the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction. As presented in Fig. 2b, the typical IV nitrogen sorption isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop demonstrates that the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction possesses mesoporous characteristics [36]. Additionally, the corresponding pore size distribution curve calculated by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) (Fig. 2c) indicates the existence of numerous mesopores in NiSe2/FeSe2. Meanwhile, the specific surface area of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction figured via Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) is 10.79 m2 g−1.

For comparison, the other various metal selenides were also fabricated with Fe-Fe PB, Co-Co PBA, Ni-Ni PBA, and Co-Ni PBA as precursors via the similar synthetic approach (details in the Experiment Section). To be specific, Fe-Fe PB was employed as a precursor for preparing FeSe2 (JCPDF #74-0247, Fig. S3a). After selenization process, the Fe-Fe PB was transformed into nano-rod morphology (Fig. S3b, c). The TEM images further show the interplanar distance of 0.248 nm, which can be attributed to the (012) plane of FeSe2 (Fig. S3d–f). Moreover, Co-Co PBA with a microcube configuration (Fig. S1c, d) was utilized for synthesizing CoSe2 (JCPDF #65-3327, Fig. S4a) [37]. As shown in Fig. S4b, c, the CoSe2 exhibits nano-bulk morphology. And the interlayer distance of 0.261 nm should be indexed into the (210) plane of CoSe2 [37] (Fig. S4d–f). Additionally, the NiSe2 (JCPDF #88-1711, Fig. S5a) was prepared via Ni-Ni PBA with a nanoplate structure (Fig. S1e, f) as the precursor. The NiSe2 possesses nano-particle morphology (Fig. S5b, c) and displays the interplanar distance of 0.266 nm, corresponding to the (210) plane of NiSe2 (Fig. S5d–f). Meanwhile, the NiSe2/CoSe2 heterojunction was fabricated by the precursor of Co-Ni PBA plate (Fig. S1g, h). The XRD pattern (Fig. S6a) indicates that the NiSe2/CoSe2 is composed of both the NiSe2 and the CoSe2, illustrating the successful construction of this desired heterojunction. Besides, The NiSe2/CoSe2 also exhibits nano-particle morphology (Fig. S6b, c), and the lattices of NiSe2 and CoSe2 can be observed in the TEM images (Fig. S6d–f), the interlayer spacing of 0.266 and 0.261 nm indexed into (210) plane of NiSe2 and (210) plane of CoSe2, respectively. This result is well in accordance with the XRD analysis and further evidences the formation of NiSe2/CoSe2 heterojunction. Furthermore, these selenides deliver alike nitrogen sorption isotherms, and their specific surface areas are very close (Fig. S7 and Table S1). Moreover, the corresponding transition-metal contents of these selenides were also determined by the ICP-OES (Table S2).

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was further performed for investigating the surface chemical composition and electronic interactions of as-prepared electrocatalysts. As displayed in Fig. 2d, the high-resolution Ni 2p spectrum of NiSe2/FeSe2 can be deconvoluted into seven characteristic peaks. The two peaks at 854.08 and 872.28 eV should be indexed into the Ni2+ 2p3/2 and Ni2+ 2p1/2, respectively. Meanwhile, the peaks at the binding energies of 857.64 and 875.91 eV can be indexed into Ni3+ 2p3/2 and Ni3+ 2p1/2, respectively. Additionally, two accompanying satellite peaks are approximately at 861.88 and 880.29 eV [38], respectively. Meanwhile, the peak located at lower binding energy can be ascribed to the Ni-Se bond [39]. For the Fe 2p spectrum of NiSe2/FeSe2 exhibited in Fig. 2e, the main peaks positioned at 711.54 and 723.45 eV are assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of Fe2+, respectively. And the other two peaks at 715.03 and 726.34 eV correspond to Fe3+ 2p3/2 and Fe3+ 2p1/2, respectively. The peaks centered at about 719.04 and 728.98 eV indicates the existence of satellite peaks of Fe 2p [40]. Besides, the peak at 707.75 eV can be assigned to the Fe-Se bond [41]. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 2f, two distinct peaks located at 54.56 and 55.61 eV belong to Se 2p5/2 and Se 2p3/2, respectively, while the peak at the binding energy of 58.58 eV is indexed into Se-O species due to the surface oxidation [42]. Notably, the binding energies of Ni 2p for NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction exhibit a negative shift of 0.52 eV in comparison with the pure NiSe2, while the binding energies of Fe 2p for NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction show a positive shift of 0.44 eV in contrast to the pure FeSe2, implying obvious electron transfer from FeSe2 to NiSe2 at the heterointerface owing to strong electronic coupling. Consequently, the charge transfer between FeSe2 and NiSe2 and the induced local charge redistribution can offer the possibility to tailor the surface electronic structure of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction, which contributes to enhance the conductivity, facilitate the adsorption for targeted reactants and thus boost the catalytic activity (confirmed by the later electrocatalytic analysis). Similarly, as shown in Figs. S8, S9, the corresponding binding energies of Co 2p for NiSe2/CoSe2 heterojunction exhibit a positive shift of 0.34 eV compared with the pure CoSe2, while the binding energies of Ni 2p for NiSe2/CoSe2 heterojunction show a negative shift of 0.32 eV relative to the pure NiSe2, which verifies charge redistribution and electron transfer between NiSe2 and FeSe2 and is deemed to be beneficial for improving the catalytic activity of NiSe2/CoSe2 heterojunction.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical activity of catalysts toward OER
ce:section.ce:para: The electrocatalytic OER behavior of the as-prepared NiSe2/FeSe2 was investigated via a standard three-electrode setup in an O2-saturated 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution at room temperature. For comparison, FeSe2, CoSe2, NiSe2, NiSe2/CoSe2 and RuO2 were also evaluated under the same criteria. The iR-corrected linear scan voltammetry (LSV) curves of all electrocatalysts are displayed in Fig. 3 a. The designed NiSe2/FeSe2 exhibits outstanding OER electrocatalytic activity with a small overpotential of 256 mV to drive 10 mA cm−2, which is much smaller than those of FeSe2 (338 mV), CoSe2 (346 mV), NiSe2 (305 mV), NiSe2/CoSe2 (304 mV) and RuO2 (381 mV). Besides, at the potential of 1.52 V vs RHE, the NiSe2/FeSe2 can deliver a bigger current density of 50 mA cm−2, superior to other contrastive samples investigated. The Tafel slopes of these samples were further calculated for clarifying the corresponding OER kinetics according to these LSV results. As shown in Fig. 3b, the NiSe2/FeSe2 demonstrates a smaller Tafel slope of 50 mV/dec in comparison with those of FeSe2 (139 mV/dec), CoSe2 (65 mV/dec), NiSe2 (91 mV/dec), NiSe2/CoSe2 (69 mV/dec) and RuO2 (91 mV/dec), implying the improved reaction kinetics of NiSe2/FeSe2. Meanwhile, the Tafel slope can afford information in connection with the catalytic mechanism. The Tafel slop between 40 and 60 mV/dec for the NiSe2/FeSe2 indicates that the formation of OO bond is the rate-limiting step during OER process [43]. Fig. 3c presents the overpotentials to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and corresponding Tafel slopes of these measured catalysts for comparing the differences of catalytic activity more visually, Moreover, as shown in Fig. S10, the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction is also lower than NiSe2-FeSe2 (296 mV, 79 mV/dec), further implying that the strong interaction in the coupled interfaces between NiSe2 and FeSe2 boost the OER activity of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction. Besides, Table S3 displays a detailed comparison of the catalytic performance for NiSe2/FeSe2 and previously reported electrocatalysts in the literature under the same conditions, illustrating that the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 possesses excellent electrocatalytic activity toward OER.

The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was also performed to investigate interfacial charge transfer between these synthesized electrocatalysts and electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 3d, the semi-circle of the NiSe2/FeSe2 is smaller than other compared samples, indicating that the NiSe2/FeSe2 has lower charge transfer resistance (Rct) and higher electrical conductivity [44]. Additionally, it should be noticed that the EIS analysis is consistent with the above Tafel slope results, explicitly demonstrating that the improved OER kinetics is due to the strong interaction between NiSe2 and FeSe2 at the interfacial region. In the meantime, the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) was further employed in the non-faradic potential range for evaluating the electrochemically active surface area of these prepared samples. As presented in Fig. S11, all these electrocatalysts exhibit similar Cdl values, implying that these samples have analogously accessible active sites toward the OER process. Moreover, the specific activity of these catalysts was determined via normalizing the current density with ECSA (Fig. 3e). Remarkably, the specific activity of the NiSe2/FeSe2 at the overpotential of 300 mV is 176.2 μA cm−2, which is much higher than those of FeSe2 (7.9 μA cm−2), CoSe2 (4.5 μA cm−2), NiSe2 (19.3 μA cm−2) and NiSe2/CoSe2 (18.9 μA cm−2). Such a high specific activity value suggests that the NiSe2/FeSe2 has enhanced intrinsic activity owing to the strong interaction at the heterointerface [45]. Meanwhile, the NiSe2/FeSe2 still presents better electrocatalytic activity than other compared samples after normalization via specific surface area (Fig. 3f), further indicating the superior intrinsic activity of the NiSe2/FeSe2 [46]. Moreover, the turnover frequency (TOF) was also calculated to clarify the intrinsic activity of these selenides [47] (Fig. S12). Notably, the TOF value of the NiSe2/FeSe2 is 1.25 s−1 at the overpotential of 350 mV, that outperforms FeSe2 (0.05 s−1), CoSe2 (0.05 s−1), NiSe2 (0.12 s−1) and NiSe2/CoSe2 (0.16 s−1). Thus, these results demonstrate that the intriguing performance of NiSe2/CoSe2 is owing to the enhanced charge transfer ability and improved intrinsic activity of active sites induced by the strong electronic couple interaction at the heterointerface.

Apart from the excellent OER activity, the electrochemical stability is also a significant criterion for evaluating the OER catalysts in large-scale applications. As presented in Fig. 4 a, a long-time chronoamperometry measurement was employed for the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterostructure. Surprisingly, no evident potential fluctuation can be observed during the stability test of 15 h at 10 mA cm−2, implying that the NiSe2/FeSe2 is stable during the OER process. Moreover, the polarization curve of the NiSe2/FeSe2 is also collected after the chronoamperometry test. As shown in Fig. 4b, the LSV curves of the NiSe2/FeSe2 before and after stability measurement are nearly identical, further indicating the superior durability of the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 heterostructure. Furthermore, the post-OER sample was also investigated by the SEM, XRD, TEM, Raman, and XPS characterizations. As displayed in Figs. 4c, d, 5 a, and S13, the structure and morphology of NiSe2/FeSe2 are well retained after the long-term test, verifying its outstanding structural stability. Besides, as exhibited in Fig. S14, the peak located at about 181 cm-1 should be attributed to the Se-Se bond of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction [33]. And the Raman peaks centered at 482 cm−1 and 680 cm−1 become obvious after the OER test, which correspond to the signal bands of nickel (iron) oxide/hydroxide [48]. Meanwhile, after the stability test, the peaks assigned to the Fe-Se bond and Ni-Se bond disappear, while the peaks corresponding to Ni3+, Fe3+, and Se-O in the high-resolution XPS spectra dramatically increases in comparison with the pristine sample (Fig. 5b–d), suggesting that the surface of NiSe2/FeSe2 catalyst is partly oxidized during the OER process. Especially, recent work has demonstrated that the electrocatalysts would be converted into related (oxy)hydroxides under high anodic oxidation, which can be regarded as the actual active sites toward OER [49]. Thus, the excellent electrocatalytic activity of NiSe2/FeSe2 should be attributed to the synergistic effect between the surface oxidized species and core selenides. The strong coupling effect and built-in electric field between NiSe2 and FeSe2 boost the electron transfer and promote the adsorption of targeted reactants due to the electrostatic interaction. Meanwhile, the in situ generated oxides/hydroxides can be served as a stabilizer to prevent the inner selenides from being continuously oxidized during the OER process, and can also be used as active sites for OER [50,51]. All these results unquestionably illustrate the superior OER activity and robust stability of the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 heterostructure.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical activity of catalysts toward UOR
ce:section.ce:para: Although the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 heterostructure displays extraordinary OER performance, the hydrogen production efficiency is still restricted by the sluggish OER kinetics in industrial applications. Hence, the OER was replaced with the oxidation of urea molecular to alleviate the restraint [52]. The UOR activity of these samples was evaluated in 1 M KOH with 0.33 M urea, which is close to the natural concentration of urea. As can be seen in Figs. 6 a and S15, when compared with the OER, all samples exhibit higher current density for UOR under the identical potential, implying that UOR is more conducive to take place at low potential than OER. Specially, the NiSe2/FeSe2 just needs a lower overpotential of 127 mV to drive 50 mA cm−2, much smaller than those of FeSe2 (346 mV), CoSe2 (348 mV), NiSe2 (183 mV) and NiSe2/CoSe2 (170 mV). Furthermore, the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction exhibits a distinctly higher current density (120 mA cm−2) at the overpotential of 200 mV than other control samples, further demonstrating the superior activity induced by the strong interaction between NiSe2 and FeSe2. Additionally, the UOR dynamics of these electrocatalysts were also studied via the corresponding Tafel slopes. As presented in Figs. 6b and S16, all these catalysts show lower Tafel slopes toward UOR in comparison with OER. The Tafel slope of the NiSe2/FeSe2 is calculated to be 32 mV/dec, that is much smaller than those of FeSe2 (115 mV/dec), CoSe2 (57 mV/dec), NiSe2 (60 mV/dec) and NiSe2/CoSe2 (39 mV/dec), illustrating the faster UOR kinetics of the NiSe2/FeSe2. Thus, the smallest overpotential at 50 mA cm−2 and the lowest Tafel slope (Fig. S17) demonstrate the extraordinary UOR activity of the NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction. Meanwhile, the NiSe2/FeSe2 still displays better electrocatalytic activity for UOR than other samples after normalization via the BET area (Fig. S18), implying its higher intrinsic activity. Moreover, the TOF was also calculated to evaluate the corresponding intrinsic activity of as-synthesized electrocatalysts toward UOR. As shown in Fig. S19, the TOF of NiSe2/FeSe2 is 1.254 s−1 at the overpotential of 200 mV, that is much higher than those of FeSe2 (0.0042 s−1), CoSe2 (0.0064s−1), NiSe2 (0.103 s−1) and NiSe2/CoSe2 (0.468 s−1), further illustrating the boosted intrinsic activity of NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction. The long-term stability is another pivotal parameter to evaluate the electrocatalysts for UOR and thus i-t measurement was performed. As displayed in Fig. 6c, the negligible fluctuation for 10 h at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 during the UOR process indicates that the NiSe2/FeSe2 possesses superior durability. Furthermore, the LSV curve of the NiSe2/FeSe2 after stability test was also obtained (Fig. 6d), which exhibits negligible variation in comparison with the pristine curve. Thus, all these systematic electrochemical investigations verify that the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 electrocatalyst has extraordinary activity and stability toward UOR.

Conspicuously, the space charge state is a vital parameter in related electrocatalytic reaction, which can contribute to a considerable effect on the adsorption of corresponding reactants, and thus should be paid special attention [53]. Then, in order to further elucidate the existence of strong interaction and charge redistribution at the interface of heterojunctions, UV–vis diffusive reflectance spectroscopy, Mott-Schottky plots, and UPS measurements were performed to establish the corresponding energy level diagrams. As presented in Fig. 7 , the band-gap energies of FeSe2, CoSe2, and NiSe2 are calculated to be about 1.91, 1.89, and 1.86 eV, respectively, in the light of the Kubelka-Munk remission function [54,55]. Moreover, the Mott-Schottky plots of FeSe2, CoSe2, and NiSe2 present negative slopes (Fig. 8 a–c), that illustrate that they are p-type semiconductors with the flat band potential (Efb) of 1.86, 2.26, and 2.38 V (vs. RHE, −6.36, −6.76 and −6.88 eV vs. vacuum level, respectively), respectively, derived from the x-intercept in the Mott-Schottky plots at 1 kHz frequency. Additionally, as presented in Fig. S20, the energy level difference between the flat band potential (Efb) and valence band potential (EVB) of FeSe2, CoSe2 and NiSe2 are determined as 0.38, 0.45 and 0.42 eV, respectively. Then, the EVB for FeSe2, CoSe2, and NiSe2 can be estimated as −6.74, −7.21, and −7.3 eV, respectively. Accordingly, the energy band diagrams of FeSe2, CoSe2, and NiSe2 and the corresponding heterojunctions can be constructed (Fig. 8d). Upon forming heterojunctions, a built-in electric field is spontaneously generated at the interface of heterojunctions owing to the remarkable difference in Fermi levels, and thus reinforce electronic interactions between single selenides. Importantly, such a built-in electric field will remarkably boost interfacial carrier transport and hence strengthen the conductivity [55], which is consistent with the above EIS results. Especially, as confirmed by the band theory of solids, the migration of electrons is closely correlated with the energy band of semiconductors. Therefore, as displayed in Fig. 8e, the self-driven electron donation from the FeSe2 and CoSe2 to NiSe2 can induce the local charge redistribution around the heterojunction interfaces and endows the surface of FeSe2 and CoSe2 with the electrophilic region, while the surface of NiSe2 is nucleophilic, in agreement with previous XPS characterizations. For further investigating the charge redistribution at the NiSe2/FeSe2 interface, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed and the structural models of NiSe2, FeSe2, and NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction were constructed (Fig. S21). As displayed in Figs. S22 and S23, the electron density difference stereograms and charges analysis indicate that electron transfer from FeSe2 to NiSe2, thus resulting in electron accumulation in the side of NiSe2 and electron depletion in the side of FeSe2. As expected, when the water and urea oxidation take place on the surface of p-p semiconductor heterojunction, the positively charged FeSe2 and CoSe2 surface are in favor of more adsorption of electron-rich OH− and the amino group of urea due to electrostatic interaction, and the electron-deficient carbonyl group of urea is inclined to be adsorbed on the negatively charged NiSe2 surface [56,57]. Thus, the constructed p-p semiconductor heterojunctions can be employed as excellent electrocatalysts for both OER and UOR. Notably, the difference in Fermi levels between FeSe2 and NiSe2 is larger than CoSe2 and NiSe2, inducing greater charge redistribution in NiSe2/FeSe2 than NiSe2/CoSe2.Therfore, NiSe2/FeSe2 heterojunction exhibits superior electrocatalytic activity than NiSe2/CoSe2 heterojunction, further accentuating the importance of the strong interfacial interaction. All these results are in line with these above XPS and electrochemical characterizations. Taken together, the superior OER and UOR activity of the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction can be ascribed to the strong coupling interaction induced by the built-in electric field around the interface, which not only facilitate the charge transfer and strengthen the conductivity, but also enhance the adsorption of these targeted reactants by electrostatic interaction.

In summary, a feasible solid-state selenization strategy has been presented to construct the NiSe2/FeSe2 p-p heterojunction for both OER and UOR. As confirmed by microscopic and spectral measurements, benefiting from the remarkable difference of energy levels between NiSe2 and FeSe2, the formed built-in electric field at the heterointerface of NiSe2/FeSe2 facilitates the charge transfer and induces local charge redistribution, which improves the conductivity and promotes the adsorption of corresponding reactants due to the electrostatic interaction. As a result, the designed NiSe2/FeSe2 electrocatalyst displays the extraordinary OER and UOR electrocatalytic activities, demanding an overpotential of 256 mV to attain the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for OER, and an overpotential of 127 mV to obtain the current density of 50 mA cm−2 for UOR, superior to the counterpart without strong built-in electric field as well as the commercial RuO2. Findings from this study are deemed to offer a brand-new avenue for regulating the surface charge state of efficient electrocatalysts through interface engineering towards future energy conversion applications.
